title: Join Us
text:
We welcome collaborators and applicants interested in AI-enabled multi-hazard forecasting, early warning systems, and decision support.
Our work combines machine learning, physical modelling, and uncertainty analysis to support risk-informed decisions for natural hazards.

title: Join Us
text:
Research themes

Multi-hazard and cascading event modelling
Machine learning for hazard detection and forecasting
Uncertainty-aware prediction and evaluation
End-to-end warning pipelines and decision support
Open tools, reproducible science, and real-world impact

title: Join Us
text:
Opportunities

PhD / MSc students
Applicants with a strong quantitative background (e.g. machine learning, statistics, physics, engineering, or geoscience) and an interest in hazards and resilience.


Postdoctoral researchers
Researchers with evidence of independent work, strong writing, and a clear research agenda aligned with the group’s themes.
We are happy to support applications to competitive postdoctoral fellowships, including:

  
    
      Marie Skłodowska-Curie Postdoctoral Fellowships
    
  
  
    
      Leverhulme Early Career Fellowships
    
  
  
    
      1951 Research Fellowships
    
  
  
    
      Newton International Fellowships
    
  
  
    
      Royal Society or UKRI-funded schemes
    
    (where applicable)
  



Research software / engineering
Researchers with experience in machine learning tooling, data pipelines, and reproducible research.

title: Research
text:
Core Research Themes




  
  
    
      
    

    
      Improving Landslide Disaster Response using AI, SAR, and Multispectral Data
    

    
      Development of AI-driven frameworks to support rapid disaster response,
      combining SAR and multispectral satellite data for landslide detection,
      mapping, and situational awareness.
    

    
      AI
      SAR
      Remote Sensing
      Disaster Response
    
  

  
  
  
    
  

    
      Neural Networks for Predicting Cascading Hazard Runouts
    

    
      Neural network models to predict runout distances and spatial impact
      of cascading hazards, including landslide–debris flow and
      multi-process gravitational mass movements.
    

    
      Neural Networks
      Cascading Hazards
      Runout Modelling
      Multihazard
    
  

  
  
    
      
    

    
      Forecasting Landslide Displacement and Failure
    

    
      Data-driven modelling of landslide displacement and time of failure using
      machine learning and hybrid physical–statistical approaches.
    

    
      Time Series
      Forecasting
      Landslides
      Uncertainty
    
  


Co-supervised Student Projects





  
    
  

  
    Neural Networks to Classify Ground-Motion Processes at Scale
  

  
    Neural network models to classify ground-motion processes from InSAR
    time series (e.g., subsidence, landslides), supporting
    rapid interpretation, and downstream hazard assessment.
  

  
    Student: Yingbo Dong,
    University of Padova - MISSLab
  

  
    Neural Networks
    Classification
    Time Series
  





  
    
  

  
    Neural Networks and LiDAR for Landslide Detection in the UK
  

  
    Development of neural network models for landslide detection using
    high-resolution LiDAR-derived terrain attributes, with applications to
    regional-scale mapping and hazard assessment across the United Kingdom.
  

  
    Student: Sankalp Kapur,
    University of Cambridge - CoMHaz

title: About
text:
The Hazard Systems Research Group (HazSys) conducts research on the use of artificial intelligence for disaster forecasting, modelling, and response.
We develop methods to anticipate and analyse interacting natural hazards, with a focus on AI-enabled forecasting, early warning systems, and decision support for disaster risk reduction. Our work combines machine learning with system-level modelling to better understand cascading impacts, uncertainty, and operational constraints.
HazSys is based at King’s College London, spanning the King’s Institute for Artificial Intelligence and the Department of Geography, and works at the interface of AI, Earth systems, and disaster risk.



AI-enabled multi-hazard forecasting and early warning

Modelling of cascading and compound disasters

Uncertainty-aware prediction and evaluation

Decision support for disaster response and adaptation




The group is led by Lorenzo Nava, AI+ Academic Senior Fellow at King’s College London.




Email: lorenava996@gmail.com

Location: King’s College London
